wikipedia_page.main: Fred Gordon Brook-Shepherd, CBE (born Fred Gordon Shepherd on 24 March 1918 in Nottingham; died 24 January 2004 in London) was a British intelligence agent, journalist, and historian. Stationed in Europe during World War II and in Vienna during Austria's occupation by the allies, he became a noted expert on the recent history of the country, especially on the lives of the last ruling Habsburgs, the psychological and political turbulence of the interwar period, and the Anschluss. He also wrote on the subject of British and Soviet intelligence.

In his book The Storm Petrels, Gordon Brook-Shepherd relates that the GPU sent Blumkin to Paris in October 1929 to assassinate the defector and former Stalin personal secretary, Boris Bazhanov. In fact, the information comes from Bazhanov himself. Although it became common gossip among the inmates of the labor camps that Blumkin had indeed killed Bazhanov, and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn repeats thar legend in The Gulag Archipelago, the truth is that Bazhanov died only in 1983. Bazhanov was then also aware of the rumour of his own murder and wrote that Stalin had probably planted the rumour himself to instill fear.
